column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-idUSKCN0YV26B	President Obama formally endorses Clinton for president	"
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama formally endorsed fellow Democrat Hillary Clinton for president on Thursday
column2: describing himself as eager to get out and campaign for her
column3: days after she gained the delegates needed to secure the party's White House nomination.""I don't think there has ever been someone so qualified to hold this office
column4: Obama said in a video released by the Clinton campaign. ""I'm with her
column5: I'm fired up and I cannot wait to get out there and campaign with Hillary.""

column1: Obama and Clinton were rivals during the 2008 Democratic primary that Obama won. Clinton went on to serve as Obama's secretary of state during his first term in office.
(Reporting by Amanda Becker
column2: Ginger Gibson and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Frances Kerry)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-agencies-idUSKCN0YV27C	House committee moves to cut funding for financial regulators	"
WASHINGTON A bill to slash funding for the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
column2: Internal Revenue Service and other financial regulators passed a key committee in the U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday after a long partisan fight.The expansive legislation would also place a halt on the payday lending restrictions that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau recently proposed.The Appropriations Committee voted 30-17 to approve the bill allocating funds for financial services and general government
column3: which now goes to the full House.One of the committee's senior Democrats
column5: warned that the ""bill in its current form will be vetoed."" The Senate must still pass accompanying legislation. After that
column6: both chambers will reconcile their bills into a single piece for President Barack Obama to sign or veto. Congress has tangled over budget laws for years
column7: and federal agencies frequently rely on temporary continuing resolutions for funding.

column1: Republicans cast the bill as a way to streamline agencies and hold them accountable for spending decisions
column2: while saving taxpayer money.Democrats attacked what they called ""riders"" to the bill
column3: such as a measure to stop the Federal Communications Commission's net neutrality rule and one to prevent corporations from being required to disclose political donations. They also said cuts to the SEC would hobble the agency in carrying out its duties and implementing the 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform law.

column1: Earlier this month the CFPB
column2: charged with shielding consumers from financial fraud
column3: proposed rules to limit short-term borrowings known as ""payday"" loans
column4: which can charge interest as high as 390 percent.Critics say the proposal will cut off credit to poor people who may need small loans during emergencies. Representative Steven Palazzo
column6: proposed an amendment on Thursday to delay implementing the rules until the bureau reports to Congress on their possible effects
column7: saying he was concerned they could force people to turn to loan sharks.

column1: Democratic National Committee Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz had been one of the few members of her party to oppose the rules
column2: and had sponsored a bill to delay CFPB rules for two years. Wasserman Schultz
column3: who is also a U.S. representative from Florida
column4: reversed her position in the last week. She told the hearing on Thursday the proposal is ""inarguably a step in the right direction
column6: ""I stand with the CFPB in its efforts to protect Americans from predatory lending.""  (Reporting by Lisa Lambert; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-endorsement-idUSKCN0YV27I	Clinton thrilled Obama 'has my back' in U.S. election: Reuters interview	"

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-puertorico-idUSKCN0YV1Y5	U.S. top court deals blow to Puerto Rico sovereignty claim	"
By Lawrence Hurley
The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that Puerto Rico cannot pursue charges against people for the same crime that federal authorities have already prosecuted them
column2: dealing a blow to the U.S. territory's claim that while it is not a state it should be treated like one.The court ruled 6-2 in favor of defendants Luis Sanchez Valle and Jaime Gomez Vazquez
column3: who were charged with illegally selling guns in 2008 by Puerto Rican authorities as well as federal prosecutors.The two pleaded guilty to the federal charges and then argued that Puerto Rico's indictments should be dismissed because of the double jeopardy clause of the U.S. Constitution that bars people from being prosecuted twice for the same offense.A trial judge dismissed the Puerto Rico charges
column4: but they were reinstated by an appeals court. In a March 2015 ruling
column5: the Puerto Rico Supreme Court ruled against prosecutors
column6: prompting the territory to appeal to the high court.

column1: On its surface
column2: the case was about criminal law. But it also raised questions about the extent to which the Caribbean island
column3: which has been a U.S. territory since 1898
column4: has sovereign powers akin to any of the 50 U.S. states. The double jeopardy clause allows U.S. states and the federal government to prosecute people separately for the same actions because they are separate sovereign entities.The Supreme Court
column5: in a ruling authored by Justice Elena Kagan
column6: said that the original source of power for Puerto Rico's Constitution came from the U.S. Congress
column8: Congress conferred the authority to create the Puerto Rico Constitution
column9: which in turn confers the authority to bring criminal charges

column1: Liberal justices Sonia Sotomayor
column2: whose parents were from Puerto Rico
column3: and Stephen Breyer dissented.Some experts saw the federal government's argument against treating Puerto Rico as a separate governmental entity as having implications for another issue: how to deal with the territory's debt crisis.

column1: In such a scenario
column2: that argument could help establish a legal precedent that Puerto Rico is not a sovereign entity
column3: possibly to justify imposing a federal control board or some other mechanism to address Puerto Rico's roughly $70 billion in debt. The U.S. Congress is currently considering legislation on the issue.The Supreme Court is expected to rule by the end of the month in another case involving Puerto Rico's bid to revive a law that would allow it to cut billions of dollars in debt at public utilities in a key test in its quest to weather its crisis. (Additional reporting by Nick Brown in San Juan)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-security-ryan-idUSKCN0YV20I	House Speaker Ryan security agenda veers from Trump's	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan unveiled a national security policy featuring stronger defense on Thursday
column2: part of his agenda to unify Republicans after a divisive primary campaign
column3: but softening some of the hard lines taken by the party's presumptive presidential nominee
column4: Donald Trump.The plan is sharply critical of President Barack Obama
column5: blaming the Democrat for ""eight years of broken promises
column7: and retreat"" in the Syrian civil war
column9: chilly relations with Russia and dealings with a bellicose North Korea.It would overturn or back away from what Obama allies see as his foreign policy achievements
column10: including the Iran deal and his moves toward normal relations with Communist-ruled Cuba. And it criticizes efforts to close the Guantanamo detention center.""It's not too much to say that our enemies no longer fear us and too many of our allies no longer trust us. And I think this is a direct result of the president's foreign policy
column11: Ryan said as he and other House Republicans introduced the plan at the Council on Foreign Relations.While not providing figures
column12: the plan also calls for an end to military rollbacks and demands ""adequate
column14: whom Ryan has endorsed in the presidential race
column15: has made a promise to erect a massive wall along the Mexican border - a centerpiece of his campaign. The plan announced on Thursday includes a range of border security measures such as ""high fencing
column17: but not a large wall.The plan echoes some of Trump's concerns about Muslim immigrants
column18: with calls to tighten refugee screening and discussion of ways to prevent the radicalization of youths.

column1: We must constantly reassess our defenses in order to find and close security gaps so that Islamist militants cannot slip into our country undetected
column2: Ryan's plan said.Representative Michael McCaul
column3: the chairman of the House of Representatives Homeland Security Committee
column4: said the intention was not to target followers of any one religion
column5: but to do everything possible to not admit those who would attack Americans.""What we have to do is target the threat and make sure that they don't come in
column7: one of several Republican committee chairmen who joined Ryan at the report presentation.

column1: NOT ISOLATIONIST
The plan is not isolationist. It takes a strong line on battling militants abroad
column2: saying the United States must keep all options on the table and ""eliminate terrorist sanctuaries."" Trump has been critical of some U.S. alliances. Ryan's plan
column3: in contrast
column4: underscores the importance of NATO. It also includes many standard Republican policy prescriptions
column5: such as strong ties to Israel
column6: advocacy of severe sanctions on Iran and an insistence that Washington should stand up to Russia.It also calls for more trade agreements and says foreign aid programs should make recipient countries self-sufficient.

column1: The plan calls for increased security for diplomats and facilities overseas. In that context
column2: it mentions the 2012 attacks on Benghazi
column3: which many Republicans cite to criticize then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column4: Trump's rival in the White House race.Several of Thursday's speakers criticized Clinton as they blasted Obama's foreign policy
column5: because she was the nation's top diplomat during the first four years of his term. Democrats sought to tie the plan to some of Trump's most controversial statements
column6: including his rejection of alliances like NATO
column7: advocacy of waterboarding and calls for attacks on the families of terrorist suspects.""Perhaps this agenda is light on details because the Republican presidential candidate has offered a truly disturbing vision of America's role in the world
column9: the top Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee
column12: has described the agenda as a way to offer voters a coherent policy message for 2017. He unveiled an anti-poverty agenda on Monday. Initiatives on regulation
column14: healthcare and tax reform are expected in the coming weeks. (Additional reporting by David Alexander
column15: writing by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Bernard Orr)"

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Thursday thanked President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden for maintaining impartiality during the primary process
column2: and said he would meet with rival Hillary Clinton soon to discuss ways to defeat Republican candidate Donald Trump.Speaking at the White House following a meeting with President Obama

column5: and said he would do everything he could to stop Trump from succeeding Obama in the November election.

column1: (Reporting by Alana Wise; Editing by James Dalgleish)"

WASHINGTON The White House said it supports legislation

9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0YV1IT	Sanders returns to Washington, meets with Obama on next steps

WASHINGTON U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders returned to Washington for meetings on Thursday with President Barack Obama and Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid as Democrats pressured him to end his presidential campaign and support Hillary Clinton after a hard-fought primary race.Clinton
column2: a former secretary of state
column3: U.S. senator and first lady
column4: secured enough delegates to secure the Democratic nomination this week and become the first woman to lead a major U.S. party as its presidential nominee.Despite Clinton's commanding victories in California and New Jersey in presidential contests on Tuesday
column5: Sanders vowed to carry his populist campaign to the Democratic National Convention in July
column6: when the party's nominee is formally chosen.Obama
column7: who is expected to endorse Clinton soon
column8: was scheduled to meet with Sanders at the White House on Thursday at 11:15 a.m. (1515 GMT). Sanders will meet with Reid
column11: which waged an unexpectedly strong challenge to a better-known and better-funded Democrat
column12: has decried what it called Clinton's anointment by the party establishment and the media.

column1: In an interview taped on Wednesday for broadcast on the NBC's ""Tonight"" show on Thursday
column2: Obama said he hoped that divisions between Democrats would start to heal in coming weeks now that Clinton has clinched the party's nomination for the Nov. 8 presidential election.At a fund-raiser in New York City on Wednesday
column3: Obama said he was not too worried about bruised feelings after the primary and said ""it was a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to have a contested primary.""

column1: Obama praised Sanders
column2: the democratic socialist senator from Vermont
column3: for bringing new energy and ideas to the party. ""He pushed the party and challenged them
column4: he said. ""I thought it made Hillary a better candidate.""Democrats are striking a delicate balance between the need to unite behind Clinton in the looming battle against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump and not alienating Sanders and his supporters.

column1: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren
column2: herself a progressive known as a fiery critic of Wall Street
column3: is preparing to endorse Clinton in the coming weeks after staying neutral in the Democratic primary
